name: Polycarp
subtitle: Apostolic Endurance and Suffering
details: Polycarp, who was the bishop of Smyrna and a direct disciple of the apostle John, encouraged his readers to persevere in their faith. He did this by highlighting the steadfast endurance of the apostles and other believers. He specifically stated that "Paul himself and the rest of the Apostles ran not in vain but in faith and righteousness," and that they "suffered." As someone who had likely known the apostles and their followers personally, Polycarp offers an early confirmation that the suffering of the apostles was closely connected to the message of the resurrection.
whyItMatters: Eyewitness connection: Polycarp's position within the "living memory" of the apostolic age adds to the credibility of the account.
Suffering linked to belief: He confirms that the endurance of the apostles was based on a conviction that was strong enough to withstand pain and persecution.
Call to perseverance: Early Christian leaders viewed the suffering of the apostles as a role model for continuous faithfulness.

source.title: The Epistle of Polycarp to the Philippians, Chapter 9, Sections 1–2 (trans. J. B. Lightfoot)
